title: 103_hr367
content: The curr_chunk is a section header titled "SHORT TITLE." The "Social Security Trust Fund Amendments of 1993" Act establishes a Board of Trustees for the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund, composed of government officials and public members nominated by the President. The Board of Trustees for the Social Security Trust Funds is composed of government officials and public members nominated by the President. The Secretary of the Treasury serves as the Managing Trustee, and the Commissioner of Social Security serves as Secretary of the Board. The Board meets at least ten times a year and is responsible for holding the Trust Funds and reporting to Congress annually on their operation and status. The Board of Trustees for the Social Security Trust Funds is responsible for reporting to Congress on the operation and status of the Trust Funds, recommending improvements in administrative procedures, reviewing general policies, approving fund investments, and ensuring funds are used solely for providing benefits and covering administrative expenses. The Managing Trustee is responsible for administering the fund with care, skill, prudence, and diligence. They must diversify investments to minimize risk and invest funds not needed for current withdrawals. Up to one-fourth of investments can be in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. The Managing Trustee is authorized to issue public-debt obligations at par for purchase by the Trust Funds, with maturities and interest rates based on market yields. Investments not needed for withdrawals will be made with approval from the Board of Trustees. The Board of Trustees will invest funds not needed for withdrawals in interest-bearing obligations of the United States or guaranteed by the United States, as well as in bonds and securities according to section (c).
